Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding and Predicting Eyewitness Identification Errors: Studies Using a Unique Set of Materials from Actual Lineups

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Forensic DNA testing has freed hundreds of innocent people in the U.S. and approximately 75% of these convictions involved mistaken eyewitness identification. The need to identify reliable ways to sort between accurate and mistaken identifications is readily apparent. Theory and data from laboratory-simulation experiments indicate that accurate and mistaken identifications differ in measurable ways (e.g., identification speed, confidence, witness verbalizations). Lab research also shows that lineup biases (e.g., innocent suspect stands out or administrator unintentionally steers the witness) can inflate mistaken identifications. Lab simulation participants, however, know that the crime is not real and fail to capture potentially important dynamics of actual witnesses (e.g., fear, justice motivations, concern for consequences).

The researchers have unique materials from actual cases involving 855 photo-lineups where only one person in each lineup was a suspect. The other lineup members were known-innocent fillers. Filler identifications, which constitute mistaken identifications, comprise 34% of all identifications. Software provided by the researchers made audio recordings of witnesses' verbalizations, speed of identifications, and other relevant information for each lineup. A majority of the lineups were administered double-blind; thus, lineup administrators were unaware of which was the suspect's photo and hence could not steer the witness. Four studies were conducted. Study 1 tests whether lineup bias predicts mistaken identifications. Study 2 tests whether witness verbalizations predict mistakes. Study 3 tests whether mistakes are slower and made with less certainty than suspect identifications. Study 4 tests whether double-blind lineup procedures evidence less steering by the lineup administrators. Data analyses involve hierarchical, mixed model log-linear analyses or ANOVAs. This work can help translate lab simulation findings to actual cases and thereby help the justice system sort between mistaken and accurate identifications. Results will be shared broadly with scientists, police and prosecutors. Undergraduate students, including first-generation and those of color at a small undergraduate college, will receive research training in this project.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mistaken eyewitness identification has been involved in over 70% of the convictions of innocent people that were later exonerated using forensic DNA testing. Although considerable advances have been made in our understanding of mistaken identifications, these advances have been restricted primarily to laboratory studies involving simulated crimes. Hence, the gap between eyewitness identification research in the lab and eyewitness identification in actual cases is potentially large.  The current studies used materials from actual cases of eyewitnesses to serious crimes who viewed lineups administered by police detectives during their ongoing investigations.

The difficulty with studies of actual eyewitnesses is establishing "ground truth" (knowing whether the suspect was the actual culprit). That is not a problem with lab studies because the researchers create the witnessed event and therefore know who the culprit is. Hence, the current studies required that there be only one suspect in each lineup and the remaining (five) lineup members were known-innocent fillers. Although an identification of the suspect might or might not be an accurate identification, the identification of a filler is a definitive mistake. Analyses were conducted under the assumption that all filler identifications are mistaken identifications whereas a significant share of all identifications of suspects are accurate identifications of the culprits. A unique characteristic of the actual lineups used in this research is that they were audio-recorded. This allowed us to extract information from the audio-recordings about witness confidence, decision time, and potential contaminating influence of lineup administrators.

Each hypothesis in these studies has been studied in the lab. With regard to confidence, lab studies show that despite an often weak confidence-accuracy correlation, high confidence (e.g., greater than 90%) witnesses are rarely cases of mistaken identification whereas lower confidence witnesses are a mix of accurate and mistaken witnesses. The results of the current studies (which scored confidence from the audio-recordings in a variety of ways) showed that high confidence witnesses were highly accurate (almost all suspect picks and no filler picks) whereas lower confidence witnesses were a mix of suspect and filler identifications. With regard to decision time, lab studies show that accurate identifications tend to occur quite quickly (within several seconds after seeing the lineup) whereas mistaken identifications are rarely fast and can take long periods of time before the witness makes the mistaken identification. Corroborating this with actual witnesses, the showed that quick identifications were almost never fillers and were almost exclusively picks of suspects. These real-case results tend to validate the lab studies on these two critical variables of confidence and decision time.

The data testing the utility of confidence and decision times were extracted from lineups in which the detective administering the lineup was blind as to which person in the lineup was the suspect and which were fillers. In the original study, all lineups were supposed to be conducted using this double-blind procedure. However,153 of the lineups were conducted non-blind by the case detective. Of these non-blind lineups, 53 made identifications of either a suspect or a filler. Because they were not randomly assigned to blind versus non-blind, we did not make inferences from the rates of suspect and filler picks about possible influence on witnesses by the lineup administrators. Such differences could be due to case characteristics. However, using the audio-recordings of these 53 non-blind lineups and audiotapes of a comparable set of 104 double-blind lineups, coders listened to each audio-recording and scored them for any attempts of the lineup administrator to influence the eyewitness. The coders were blind as to whether the lineup administrator was blind or not and also blind as to whether the witness identified a suspect or identified a filler. The primary measure for the coders was their guess as to whether the lineup administrator was blind or not. The results wshowed that coders could significantly sort between blind and non-blind lineup administrators based solely on the audiotapes. Predictive modeling analyses showed that non-blind administrators tended to push eyewitnesses toward a particular lineup member more than did double-blind administrators, thereby showing a strong replication of laboratory studies. This finding is the first evidence that actual police detectives administering lineups (rather than lab participants assigned to administer lineups) engage in suggestive behaviors when they are not blind. This is an important finding because one of the points of resistance in some police jurisdictions against implementing double-blind lineups is that double-blind administration is unnecessary because police are capable of totally-objective testing and their professionalism prevents them from influencing witnesses.

The outcomes of this work indicate that three of the most important lab-based findings  are corroborated by data from actual cases. This should reduce skepticism in some police jurisdictions about the value of lab studies for simulating the real world of eyewitnesses and stimulate other researchers to conduct additional studies using actual eyewitnesses in ongoing cases. 


Last Modified: 03/19/2019
Modified by: Gary L Wells
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Mistaken eyewitness identification has been involved in over 70% of the convictions of innocent people that were later exonerated using forensic DNA testing. Although considerable advances have been made in our understanding of mistaken identifications, these advances have been restricted primarily to laboratory studies involving simulated crimes. Hence, the gap between eyewitness identification research in the lab and eyewitness identification in actual cases is potentially large. The current studies used materials from actual cases of eyewitnesses to serious crimes who viewed lineups administered by police detectives during their ongoing investigations. The difficulty with studies of actual eyewitnesses is establishing "ground truth" (knowing whether the suspect was the actual culprit). That is not a problem with lab studies because the researchers create the witnessed event and therefore know who the culprit is. Hence, the current studies required that there be only one suspect in each lineup and the remaining (five) lineup members were known-innocent fillers. Although an identification of the suspect might or might not be an accurate identification, the identification of a filler is a definitive mistake. Analyses were conducted under the assumption that all filler identifications are mistaken identifications whereas a significant share of all identifications of suspects are accurate identifications of the culprits. With regard to decision time, lab studies show that accurate identifications tend to occur quite quickly (within several seconds after seeing the lineup) whereas mistaken identifications are rarely fast and can take long periods of time before the witness makes the mistaken identification. Corroborating this with actual witnesses, the showed that quick identifications were almost never fillers and were almost exclusively picks of suspects. Predictive modeling analyses showed that non-blind administrators tended to push eyewitnesses toward a particular lineup member more than did double-blind administrators, thereby showing a strong replication of laboratory studies. This finding is the first evidence that actual police detectives administering lineups (rather than lab participants assigned to administer lineups) engage in suggestive behaviors when they are not blind. The outcomes of this work indicate that three of the most important lab-based findings are corroborated by data from actual cases. This should reduce skepticism in some police jurisdictions about the value of lab studies for simulating the real world of eyewitnesses and stimulate other researchers to conduct additional studies using actual eyewitnesses in ongoing cases.
